etymologies: late 16th century; earliest use found in John Lyly (1554–1606), writer and playwright. From classical Latin hippomanes small black fleshy substance said to occur on the forehead of a newborn foal, mucous secretion discharged by mares in heat from ancient Greek ἱππομανές small black fleshy substance said to occur on the forehead of a newborn foal, in Hellenistic Greek also mucous secretion discharged by mares in heat, both substances said to be aphrodisiacs, use as noun of neuter of ἱππομανής abounding in horses, in Byzantine Greek also mad on horses from ἱππο- + μαν-, root of μαίνεσθαι to be mad

definitions: Originally: †a fleshy excrescence believed to occur on the forehead or in the mouth of a newborn foal and to act as an aphrodisiac (obsolete). In later use: a small flat mass, typically white, yellow, brown, or black in colour and primarily composed of cellular debris, found in the allantoic fluid of equids.
A mucous vaginal secretion occurring in a mare in heat, formerly thought to act as an aphrodisiac or to provoke madness.
